And one last thing to keep in mind is that there are two main types of objects: Native Described in the ECMAScript standard Host Defined by the host environment (for example, the browser environment)
There are no classes in JavaScript.

the prototype is an object (not a class or anything special) and every function has a prototype property.

Version 5 adds some new built-in objects, methods, and properties to the language, but its most important addition is the so-called strict mode, which actually removes features from the language, making the programs simpler and less error-prone.
ES5 is a transitional version — developers are encouraged, but not forced, to write code that works in strict mode.

To avoid clutter, some code snippets skip it, too, and assume you’re testing the code in the console: window.name === window['name']; // true This is as if we used the following: console.log(window.name === window['name']); and it printed true in the console.
It’s therefore critical to reduce the time it takes to understand code, either written by yourself some time ago or written by another developer in the team.
Maintainable code means code that: Is readable Is consistent Is predictable Looks as if it was written by the same person Is documented
JavaScript has the notion of implied globals, meaning that any variable you don’t declare becomes a property of the global object
after calling the function you end up with one more variable result in the global namespace that can be a source of problems.
Another antipattern that creates implied globals is to chain assignments as part of a var declaration.
If you’ve already declared the variables, chaining assignments is fine and doesn’t create unexpected globals
implied globals are technically not real variables, but they are properties of the global object.
the global object is accessible from any part of the code via the window property
This is actually no longer the case in ECMAScript 5 in strict mode, so you have to adopt a different pattern when your code is in strict mode.
Using a single var statement at the top of your functions is a useful pattern to adopt.
and declare multiple variables delimited by commas. It’s a good practice to also initialize the variable with an initial value at the time you declare it.
For JavaScript, as long as a variable is in the same scope (same function), it’s considered declared, even when it’s used before the var declaration

Ending the switch with a default: to make sure there’s always a sane result even if none of the cases matched.

And what about variables that are not functions? Developers commonly use lower camel case for variable names, but another good idea is to use all lowercase words delimited by an underscore: for example, first_name, favorite_bands, and old_company_name. This notation helps you visually distinguish between functions and all other identifiers — primitives and objects.
use an underscore prefix to denote a private method or property.
the obvious: every single variable or every single line. But you usually need to document all functions, their arguments and return values, and also any interesting or unusual algorithm or technique.

The code you write will be read (by humans), so make it easy for the maintainer to understand it quickly and let the minifier (the machine) take care of reducing the file sizes.
why the literal is the preferred pattern for object creation
The immediate function pattern is widely used. It helps you wrap an amount of work you want to do without leaving any global variables behind.
Caching the results of a function is also known as memoization.
Passing a large number of parameters is not convenient. A better approach is to substitute all the parameters with only one and make it an object;
what we think of calling a function is not much more than syntactic sugar, equivalent to a function application
The process of making a function understand and handle partial application is called currying.

Currying has nothing to do with the spicy Indian dish; it comes from the name of the mathematician Haskell Curry. (The Haskell programming language is also named after him.) Currying is a transformation process — we transform a function. An alternative name for currying could be schönfinkelisation, after the name of another mathematician, Moses Schönfinkel, the original inventor of this transformation.

When schonfinkelize() is called the first time, it stores a private reference to the slice() method (called slice) and also stores the arguments it was called with (into stored_args), only stripping the first, because the first argument is the function being curried.
When you find yourself calling the same function and passing mostly the same parameters, then the function is probably a good candidate for currying.
Self-defining functions Overwrite themselves with new bodies to do less work from the second invocation and after

The Occult (Wilson, Colin).Text: man is more deeply moved by meaning than by accident.
He must turn increasingly inward. That is, he must turn to the hidden levels of his being,

The power to be derived from this ‘fearful passionless force’ is only incidentally a power over things and people. It is basically power over oneself, contact with some ‘source of power, meaning and purpose’ in the subconscious mind.
we are dealing with a faculty that may be called a sixth sense, a subconscious faculty by comparison with which our powers of conscious observation are clumsy and inaccurate.
A poet is simply a man in whom the links with our animal past are still strong.
This sense of ‘meanings’ that are not apparent to ordinary consciousness is experienced by everyone at some time or another.

there is a kind of ‘psychic ether’ that carries mental vibrations as the ‘luminiferous ether’ is supposed to carry light. This I would define as the fundamental proposition of magic or occultism, and perhaps the only essential one. It will be taken for granted throughout this book.
‘Objectivity’ causes power to flow into the soul, a surge of strength, and contact with the vast, strange forces that surround us.
